Evaluation_Questions: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Comments_Questions: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
Comments_List: I came into this class without ever having analyzed a philosophical argument, and now I am not only comfortable analyzing such arguments in class, but also writing about them. It's a very particular skill and I'm grateful to have more insight into the nature of philosophical arguments.

I came into this class with zero philosophical knowledge. Now I can confidently say I know how to write a structured philosophy paper and use basic philosophical terms. I also have a solid ground understanding of the big tenants of philosophy.
How to think philosophically, engage with philosophical texts, and how to write argumentatively. In short, a lot, and it was great.
Learned  how to write a philosophy paper, learned philosophical reasoning skills, how to discuss philosophical texts

I know feel as if I better understand what philosophy is, why it is important and how it has evolved. Entering, as I did, with absolutely no knowledge of philosophy I have come to understand how to engage with the philosophical ideas of other and how to develop my own.
I learned how to digest philosophical texts charitably; write clearly and thoroughly; and work through arguments and counter arguments in a methodical manner.

I got a very good but brief overview of classic philosophy. I learned how to dissect arguments and present strong objections. We went from Plato and Aristotle through the Stoics, Skeptics and Epicureans all the way through to the Christians Augustine, Aquinas and Anselm with more in between.
I learned how to interpret philosophical arguments.
I learnt how to write philosophically and approach texts more critically.

I learned how to analyze philosophical arguments and to convey my own ideas clearly and concisely in a philosophy paper. I also improved my ability to read dense texts and to participate productively in seminar discussions.

The strength of this course was the class discussion, led by Professor Dembroff. They did an amazing job of letting us explore the avenues we were interested in, while keeping us on track with insightful follow up questions. Some professors want to dominate the conversation, but Professor Dembroff, gratefully, is not one of them-- and yet, my DS discussion in their section was better than all my other sections. The weakness of the course lies in the nature of DS: I'd like more time to discuss each book, but the sheer number of authors that we plow through precludes us from doing so. Overall, a sacrifice I'm willing to make, but it still can be frustrating at times. I'd like to see more diversity in the curriculum and rotating cast of lecturers, though. Philosophy, for whatever reason, seems to have the most trouble in that respect, compared to the other two DS disciplines.
I wish there had been more resources and examples of how to properly write a philosophical paper, resources geared towards complete beginners.

The greatest strength is how interesting class discussion is. Seminars were always helpful and made me think critically about he text and my own ideas. On the weaknesses, it's difficult to engage fully with the works we read when given so little time to read and then discuss them.

The authors and texts covered in this course were exactly what I had hoped to have read upon exiting. I think discussion was too often caught up in minutiae and therefore missed larger important issues.

A weakness (inherent in Directed Studies) is the fast pace: there's a lot of ground to cover, leaving little time to really work through texts and understand them at a deeper level. At the same time, the breadthbeing able to touch upon so many essential texts and see the conversations between authors across the centuriesis also its greatest strength.

The course covers a very large period of time, so discussions can't always be super in-depth, but it appears to be a necessary sacrifice for the sheer breadth of knowledge you can gain. A great strength of this course is how intertwined all the works are. Their commonalities make for such fruitful discussion especially later in the semester when were able to compare authors and their arguments.
The course would be improved by more consistent, regular testing of our knowledge of each work.

The strengths were the professors who lectured and led section and the works studied. A weakness was perhaps spending so much time on Aristotle when we didn't even cover Boethius or Plato's 'Symposium'.

The strengths of the course include engaging seminar discussions, challenging and stimulating texts, and great professors. Weaknesses include a fast-paced reading schedule. This means that the class spends less time on each of the texts than they probably deserve.
Yes, I would recommend DS to another student, while keeping in mind that most students do not opt into the program, and there are valid reasons to make this choice. I'm happy with my choice, though.

Yes, I would recommend DS Philosophy. I finally understand the big ideas attached to the names of thinkers we throw around all the time: Aristotle, Plato, etc. This course offers a good foundation and intro into Philosophy, and is suitable for people who never have taken it before.
Yes, great introduction to philosophy
Yes! This is a great complement to other DS courses and is worthwhile even if philosophy isn't your thing.

Absolutely! But, Directed Studies really isn't for everyone. It really limits exploration of courses in your first year, a perfect time to explore different fields. I've thoroughly enjoyed it so far, though.

I would recommend this course to anyone with an interest in philosophy, regardless of skill level. It's a lot of work, but if the right time is spent, it will change how you view yourself and your outlook on life.
Yes, it is good to learn about the foundation of modern philosophy through reading and writing papers in this manner.
DS Philosophy is a challenge but very rewarding once you start to understand the texts. Sections provide interesting discussions and Prof Dembroff is great if you're lucky enough to get them.
Yes, I would recommend this course. It was my favorite of the semester, and I found it to be both personally meaningful and intellectually engaging.
